_prev_prog_3.CH_OtherChanges: eliminated one site, revised PSM/RMP program, conducted a hazmat drill
_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: all hazmat response equipment( a- Level Suits/SCBA's/Decon equipment/ammonia detector
_prev_prog_3.Description: All equipment is state of the art and installed under the supervision of PermaCold Engineering. Our refrigeration department employees maintain a strict schedule of daily, weekly, and monthly checks to all parts of the ammonia system. Our company has been under consultation with OR- Our PHA is complete and recommendations have been corrected. The system is monitored for leaks and has an alarm system with a nuisance alarm that goes off at 35ppm . Building is then evacuated, until the Cell Tech refridgeration department has checked it out and deemed the building safe for employees to return to work.10/14/04 we had an external safety agency perform a safety audit.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary

Attached File Name:       South 6th St

New Earth has 14,000 pounds of anhydrous ammonia, (total capacity) and 12,000-pound actual product in the system, used solely as a refrigerant at 1350 South 6th Street.  The system was built in 1995 under the supervision of PermaCold Engineering.  This new system incorporated the latest in new technogly and conformed to all safety standards.  Alarm sensors were installed that detect the smallest leak of 35ppm.  The building is evacuated and the refrigeration department is paged by the computer system.  A second alarm goes off if PPM reaches 250.  The system then shuts down the plant.  If the PPM is 300 or above the refrigeration department calls 911.Some employees are trained and certified as State Industrial Hazmat Technicians.  These employees will supplement the State Hazmat Team as needed.

New Earth does an annual drill, (11/04) all in conjunction with the local State Hazmat Team.  Our trainer, Monte Keady, is a member of the State Team and a local firefighter.

All floor plans and any updates to our written response plan are shared with the local State team.  Tours are given as needed to the local State team to keep them familiar with the facilities.

New Earth has all the response equipment required for an A-level response.  We have SCBA'S, 4 level A suits, decontamination equipment, escape masks, laptop computers, radios, ladders, fans, tarps, hoses, heavy equipment if needed, and B-level suits.  Hazmat team members are trained on such equipment and receive annual physicals.

The maintenance department performs daily, weekly, monthly, quarterly, and annual inspection checks.  A computer program reminds the department of needed scheduled maintenance.  Other repairs are made and recorded as needed.

New Earth was under OR-OSHA Consultation for Process Safety Management during the initial writing of this program.  Process Hazard Analysis have been conducted using the what if method.  Recommendations hav

e been made for such things as administrative controls, line-breaking procedures, forklift-restricted areas, more maintenance checks, and some other minor changes, none of which sparked a Management of Change procedure.

Training is given on a as needed basis for the refrigeration department. Employees who work in or around the ammonia receive ammonia training on an annual basis.  The most recent one was October 18, 2004.

The safety committee does quarterly inspections of the facility.  Material Safety Data Sheet books are up to date and area where ammonia is used is in great shape.  All valves and parts are labeled according to the Piping, & Instrumentation Diagrams that are posted in each room.  All chemicals are labeled according to their contents.

There have been no accidents at this facility.  The systems that are in place, the drills, safety practices, and training that New Earth goes through, make an accidental release very unlikely, baring natural disasters.
